threads.com: I just went outside and saw my dad standing at the edge of our driveway looking off into the distance. He saw me and made a hand gesture to come over to him so I started walking, he yelled to hurry so I ran over and he grabbed my arm tight and pulled me toward him and yelled, "Look there it's a UFO!" I looked in the direction he was pointing and sure enough there was what looked like some rotating disc hovering at a diagonal angle in the sky. It is night and fairly dark but I am pretty sure I could discern the outline enough to tell it was a disc. The lights all glowed red and blinked at the same time while rotating around in a disc like formation anyways, which I'm pretty sure our planes don't do. We watched the thing for a moment and it flew over the trees disappearing behind the horizon eventually. In hindsight one of us should have probably filmed it but that didn't happen so I did my best to make a rendition of what it looked like in paint 3d. I have never shared anything here before and this is not a larp or or glowy disinfo or anything like that. I'm not saying it is aliens or that they talked to me or anything just that we saw their spooky craft. Hope this story helps someone in their research and that I don't get deleted over it.

The first element of Nazi occult beliefs was in the mythic land of Hyperborea-Thule. Just as Plato had cited the Egyptian legend of the sunken island of Atlantis, Herodotus mentioned the Egyptian legend of the continent of Hyperborea in the far north. When ice destroyed this ancient land, its people migrated south. Writing in 1679, the Swedish author Olaf Rudbeck identified the Atlanteans with the Hyperboreans and located the latter at the North Pole. According to several accounts, Hyperborea split into the islands of Thule and Ultima Thule, which some people identified with Iceland and Greenland.

The second ingredient was the idea of a hollow earth. At the end of the seventeenth century, the British astronomer Sir Edmund Halley first suggested that the earth was hollow, consisting of four concentric spheres. The hollow earth theory fired many people’s imaginations, especially with the publication in 1864 of French novelist Jules Verne’s Voyage to the Center of the Earth.

In Native American mythology, it is said that the ancestors of the Mandan people in ancient times emerged from a subterranean land through a cave at the north side of the Missouri River.[14] There is also a tale about a tunnel in the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation in Arizona near Cedar Creek which is said to lead inside the Earth to a land inhabited by a mysterious tribe.[15] It is also the belief of the tribes of the Iroquois that their ancient ancestors emerged from a subterranean world inside the Earth.[16] The elders of the Hopi people believe that a Sipapu entrance in the Grand Canyon exists which leads to the underworld.[17][18]

Brazilian Indians, who live alongside the Parima River in Brazil, claim that their forefathers emerged in ancient times from an underground land, and that many of their ancestors still remained inside the Earth. -don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

On the Joe Rogan Experience episode with Travis Walton as the guest, Walton explains a few differences from his actual story from the film "Fire in the Sky".

One of these is that after Walton woke up on the table and started going apeshit on the ayys, they quickly left the room. After a moment, Walton described a human, or at least something resembling a human or in his words "he looked like someone you could pass by in a crowd and not notice anything out of the ordinary" enter the room. Walton described the being or man as a man with long light brown hair, wearing a full body jump/worksuit that was blue, and also was wearing a helmet that resembled a "fish bowl" on his head. Walton said the man did not talk to him when Walton tried to ask him where he was. The man only smiled and gently grabbed him by the arm and led him out of the room where he saw several other humans or humanoid figures, at least one of which was a woman, all wearing blue jumpsuits and not talking. They all took him back into the room after a while and fit a mask over him and possibly put him under a sort of anesthesia, and the next thing he knew he woke up on Earth.

More info can be found in the podcast, I apologize for not linking it with a timestamp but I could not find it on youtube, I think that episode is only on spotify.

Who were those humans he met? It is obvious who the ayys were. They were the greys, but the humans? Were they the hyperboreans? Were they just greys who used a cloaking device to make them appear as familiar faces to calm Walton down? Were they ancient humans? Walton doesn't elaborate on the race of the humans he encountered on the ship but he does mention the light brown hair, and this makes me think it could only be white people. Sounds like nordics/hyperboreans to me. Were they ancient humans who had ascended and are now timeless? Was Walton full of shit? I don't think so but I'm not sure. I really just want theories on the humans he encountered on the ship.

>Have you ever seen or encountered a sasquatch.
I don't think so. I lived in Northern California till I was 14 and both my parents worked for the United States Forest Service at separate times, and neither of them ever saw anything despite being out in the woods in state parks. The only reason that I say "think" is because I had one single solitary kind of strange incident. Let me preface this by stating that I was about 12 years old when it happened and, at the time, I was 100% convinced that it was a black bear. Basically, what happened was that my mother was driving us home, it was dark, probably around 8:00PM or so, and we were the only car on the road just slightly outside of town. Not that far from a supermarket at all, maybe half a mile away, so it wasn't deep woods or anything. Anyways, as we're driving, up ahead a ways, we see a large black animal run on all fours across the road. That was it. As I said, at the time, I was 100% convinced it was a bear. It's only many years later when I started to hear about certain reports about them running on all fours that I began to wonder about it in retrospect. It was probably a bear, but nowadays, I'm simply not certain. Keep in mind that this is way up in northern California, total Bigfoot hotspot territory. I've even been to Mount Shasta many times for fishing and stuff, and apparently people go missing there all the time. Pretty spooky in hindsight. As far as something that was clearly a bigfoot though, I never saw anything. My mother did once tell me with a totally straight face that she once saw a UFO rising out of the woods though, which was extremely uncharacteristic for her, since she had never expressed any interest in UFO's or anything of the sort before. She just kind of blurted it out at me one day and then never spoke of it again. Take that for what it's worth.
